At 22:49 26/02/2006, you wrote:
>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>
> >So the speciation works that I run the main species (fitness in red)
> >until it stalls for 100,000 cycles (the side population appears as
> >zeros on the graphs during this phase).  Then I take one individual,
> >mutate it to pieces and use it to see the side population.  I then
> >run the side population until it stalls (the main population appears
> >frozen at its last value during this phase).  I then merge the two
> >populations (by one of several experimental techniques) overwrite the
> >main population with the result, scrap the side-population and return
> >to the initial phase (exolving main).
> >
> >
>Err yeh I'm still with you. I notice the side species fitness does
>indeed exceed the main species on some occasions and on other occasions
>the merging of the two causes an increase.

Sometimes it does, but my current merge technique is "destructive" 
(in the terminology I used when I discussed this before) so that 
means that I can also sometimes lose ground on a merge.

There are ways to make any merge "preserving", e.g. by including both 
the parent population champions in a the child population.  But I'm 
not sure that wouldn't defeat the purpose of the merge, because my 
species are small here, and if I put a very fit champion on top of a 
lot of only potentially fit hybrids, it might well just displace them 
all before they could demonstrate their potential.  OTOH, if I keep 
the species champions _and_ the merged species then I have 
effectively increased the number of species in the merge, instead of 
decreasing it...

>  In other words it seems to be
>working. So are you going to try with multiple side species next?

My thoughts are straying in that direction.  OTOH, less species = 
faster exploration of the ones we have so...

> >
> >I am also inclined to say that the system as I have it has a net
> >drive towards smaller individuals (look at the line of the purple and
> >blue curves from 2.5 MCycles upwards) and that the individuals (i)
> >grow in size when it is discovering additions that make then fitter,
> >but, (ii) then slowly squeezes their existing fitness into a smaller
> >genomes when they are not finding any obvious additions.
> >
> >There's a solid mathematical reason why the net drive is downwards,
> >which I am aching to explain to you all.  Does anybody want to know?
> >
> >
>Oh go on then. I'll be watching CSI but I am listening, honest ;)

It'll take 1/2 hour to type in, so I'll try to do it tomorrow...

         Ian

In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
